unnormalised: My journey into the world of fintech began, like many others in India, with a frustrating experience. I was trying to send money to my grandmother, Amma, back in Kerala. The bank queues were long, the forms complicated, and the entire process felt like stepping back into the 1980s. I remember thinking, "There has to be a better way!" This was back in 2015, before UPI became the household name it is today.
normalised: My journey into the world of fintech began, like many others in India, with a frustrating experience. I was trying to send money to my grandmother, Amma, back in Kerala. The bank queues were long, the forms complicated, and the entire process felt like stepping back into the nineteen eighties. I remember thinking, "There has to be a better way!" This was back in two thousand and fifteen, before U-P-I became the household name it is today.

unnormalised: At that time, Paytm was just starting to gain traction. I remember seeing ads everywhere – rickshaws, buses, even the local chai stall. I hesitantly downloaded the app and attempted my first transaction. It wasn't perfect, but it was significantly faster and easier than the traditional banking route. I transferred Rs. 2000 to Amma, and she received it almost instantly. She was amazed! She called me, excitedly asking how this magic happened. That was my first real exposure to the power of fintech.

I hesitantly downloaded the app and attempted my first transaction. It wasn't perfect, but it was significantly faster and easier than the traditional banking route. I transferred rupee two thousand to Amma, and she received it almost instantly. She was amazed! She called me, excitedly asking how this magic happened. That was my first real exposure to the power of fintech.

unnormalised: Intrigued, I started researching other fintech companies in India. I stumbled upon a small startup called "Lendbox" that was offering peer-to-peer lending. The concept was fascinating – individuals lending money directly to other individuals, bypassing traditional banks. They boasted interest rates of 12% p.a., far higher than what banks were offering at the time. I initially invested a small amount, around ₹5000, to test the waters.

They boasted interest rates of twelve percent per annum, far higher than what banks were offering at the time. I initially invested a small amount, around rupee five thousand, to test the waters.

unnormalised: Over the next few years, I witnessed the explosive growth of India's fintech ecosystem. Companies like PhonePe, BharatPe, and CRED emerged, each offering innovative solutions for payments, lending, and credit. I saw neighborhood kirana stores accepting UPI payments through QR codes – a sight unimaginable just a few years prior. Even Amma, who initially struggled with the concept, now uses Paytm to pay her local vegetable vendor.

Even Amma, who initially struggled with the concept, now uses Paytm to pay her local vegetable vendor.

unnormalised: One pivotal moment came during the demonetization in 2016. With physical cash suddenly scarce, digital payment platforms experienced an unprecedented surge in adoption. People who had never used a smartphone before were forced to learn how to transact online. This event, while initially disruptive, accelerated the digital transformation of the Indian economy and gave a massive boost to the fintech sector.

unnormalised: I recall reading an article in the Economic Times highlighting how UPI transactions crossed Rs 1 lakh crore for the first time, a truly watershed moment. It felt like India was finally leapfrogging into the future. The sheer volume of digital transactions was staggering, and it was all being powered by homegrown fintech solutions.

unnormalised: However, the rapid growth also brought its own set of challenges. Cybersecurity threats became more prevalent, and concerns about data privacy increased. I remember reading about scams targeting unsuspecting users, particularly in rural areas where digital literacy was still low. It became clear that robust regulatory frameworks and user education were crucial for the sustainable growth of the fintech industry.

unnormalised: Recently, I came across a new platform called "Groww" that allows users to invest in mutual funds and stocks directly from their smartphones. They offer a user-friendly interface and educational resources, making investing accessible to a wider audience. I’ve started experimenting with smaller SIP investments, hoping to build a diversified portfolio over time. The potential for wealth creation through these platforms is immense.

unnormalised: Looking back at my fintech journey, I am amazed by how much has changed in such a short period. From struggling with bank queues to effortlessly sending money to Amma via UPI, the transformation has been remarkable. Fintech has democratized access to financial services, empowered small businesses, and fueled economic growth.

Fintech has democratized access to financial services, empowered small businesses, and fueled economic growth.

unnormalised: And while challenges remain, I am optimistic about the future of fintech in India. With continued innovation, responsible regulation, and a focus on user education, fintech has the potential to transform India into a truly cashless and financially inclusive society. Just imagine – a future where even the smallest tea stall accepts digital payments and everyone has access to affordable financial services. That is the promise of fintech, and it's a promise I believe India is well on its way to fulfilling.
